so- or the nodes or the vertices.
So it's plus 1 if edge j points into node i,

X_3 are going out and you subtract them, and that's, kind of,
the net amount that's flowing into node 2.
So that's the idea.
That's- that's what matrix vector multiplication does when you have an incidence matrix.
It converts a flow into the net flows at all of the nodes.
So that's- that's the idea.
Now, a very special equation is AX equals 0,
and that's called flow conservation.
And in that case, if- if X ends by that,
it's called a circulation, right?
And that's super interesting because what it means is,
flow conservation says that the totally-
the net amount flow- the total amount- the net amount flowing into the node is 0.
And that means that the total amount flowing in on incoming edges exactly
balances the total- the total flow going out of the node on outgoing edges.
So that- that's flow conservation.
So if this was an electrical circuit,
you would say this would be called Kirchhoff's Current Law.
And it basically says that all the current coming into that node go and,
you know, balances exactly all the current going out of it.
So that's- that- that's the context in which it comes up and it's called the circulation.

you get something super interesting.

1, 1, minus 1.
And in fact, if you multiply such a vector by- if you multiply- sorry,
such that if you have the inner product of that vector with another vector,
what you're doing is you're taking the difference of two entries.
So it turns out the following is what happens.
It turns out that a transpose V is super interesting.
What it is, is it's an m-vector of the potential differences across the m-edges.
Right. So again, in electrical engineering,

and V could represent the voltage at each node.
Then when you form a transpose V,
what you're getting is a vector,
which is the length of the edges and it tells you
the voltage difference across each of the edges.

something else related to potentials,um,
is something called the Dirichlet energy.

It's this: What it is- is- it is the norm squared
of a transpose V. V is a potential, a vector of potentials.
And so as you know,
a transpose V gives you a vector now associated with the edges.
Each- each component of a transpose V is- corresponds to an edge,
and it gives you the difference in the potential across that edge.
Okay. And if you take the sum of the squares of them,
that gives you the so-called Dirichlet energy.
And so here's one way to write that.
This says that you only sum- you sum over the edges on- on the graph.
So whenever two nodes are adjacent, I didn't say that,
but when two nodes are connected by an edge,
you would say that they are adjacent.
So this says that you'd- you'd sum over the potential differences.

You should think of the Dirichlet energy as an interesting thing.

In other words, it's a multiple of the 1s vector.
Why? Because in that case all of these are 0,
because every entry of the vector is the same.
You subtract them, you get 0,
and you sum and square them, you get 0.
Otherwise, what this is- is,
it's something that measures,
I'll say it very roughly,
how wiggly your potential V is across the graph.
